identificationModule.briefTitle: Preliminary Evaluation of [68Ga]CBP8 in Healthy Individuals, Lung Cancer, and Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis Patients
identificationModule.officialTitle: Preliminary Evaluation of [68Ga]CBP8 in Healthy Individuals, Lung Cancer Patients Undergoing Radiation Therapy Prior to the Resection of Locally Advanced Tumors, and Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis Patients

collaborators.name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The goal of this study is to investigate the safety of \[68Ga\]CBP8 and its efficacy to detect collagen deposition in pulmonary fibrosis.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
The investigators have developed \[68Ga\]CBP8, a gallium-68 labeled collagen binding PET imaging probe, which selectively binds collagen type I. Collagen deposition is a pivotal event in several human conditions including pulmonary fibrosis. The investigator's studies in mice showed that \[68Ga\]CBP8 binds collagen with high affinity and has excellent pharmacological and pharmacokinetic profiles with high target uptake and low retention in background tissues and organs. \[68Ga\]CBP8 was shown in a mouse model to be effective for detecting lung fibrosis. \[68Ga\]CBP8 showed high specificity for pulmonary fibrosis and high target:background ratios in diseased animals. In addition, \[68Ga\]CBP8 could be used to monitor response to treatment. Ex vivo analysis of lung tissue from patients with IPF supported the animal findings.

The investigators thus aim to perform the first in human studies of \[68Ga\]CBP8:

1. To evaluate the safety of \[68Ga\]CBP8 and its whole body distribution, metabolism, pharmacokinetics, and radiation burden in healthy volunteers.
2. To establish the accuracy of \[68Ga\]CBP8-PET to detect radiation-induced fibrosis in lung cancer patients and correlate collagen-targeted \[68Ga\]CBP8-PET imaging with HRCT and histology in lung cancer patients.
3. To determine whether collagen deposition as assessed by \[68Ga\]CBP8-PET molecular imaging can predict disease progression in IPF patients and patients with other types of ILD with a fibrotic component.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Healthy control subjects will be enrolled first and then subjects with lung cancer and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis or other types of interstitial lung disease with a fibrotic component meeting inclusion criteria.

armGroups.label: Healthy Individuals
armGroups.description: Healthy volunteers will receive \[68Ga\]CBP8 and undergo PET imaging.

armGroups.label: Lung Cancer Subjects
armGroups.description: Lung cancer patients will receive \[68Ga\]CBP8 and undergo PET imaging.

armGroups.label: Pulmonary Fibrosis Subjects
armGroups.description: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis patients or patients with other types of interstitial lung disease with a fibrotic component will receive \[68Ga\]CBP8 and undergo PET imaging.

interventions.name: [68Ga]CBP8
interventions.description: Up to 15 mCi of \[68Ga\]CBP8 will be administered to each subject.

interventions.name: PET Imaging
interventions.description: All subjects will undergo PET imaging after administration of \[68Ga\]CBP8.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Ability to detect increased collagen deposition in pulmonary fibrosis.
primaryOutcomes.description: Probe lung uptake will be measured in pulmonary fibrosis subjects and compared to lung uptake in healthy volunteers. We expect greater uptake in the lungs of IPF patients and patients with other types of ILD with a fibrotic component.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Ability of the degree of collagen deposition to predict disease progression.
secondaryOutcomes.description: Probe lung uptake in pulmonary fibrosis patients will be correlated with change in forced vital capacity over the prior 12 months and prospectively over the following 12-36 months.

otherOutcomes.measure: Ability of [68Ga]CBP8 to detect collagen deposition in areas of radiation injury.
otherOutcomes.description: Probe lung uptake will be measured in lung cancer patients prior to surgical resection and compared to histologic measures of fibrosis.

references.citation: Desogere P, Tapias LF, Hariri LP, Rotile NJ, Rietz TA, Probst CK, Blasi F, Day H, Mino-Kenudson M, Weinreb P, Violette SM, Fuchs BC, Tager AM, Lanuti M, Caravan P. Type I collagen-targeted PET probe for pulmonary fibrosis detection and staging in preclinical models. Sci Transl Med. 2017 Apr 5;9(384):eaaf4696. doi: 10.1126/scitranslmed.aaf4696.

Desogere P, Tapias LF, Rietz TA, Rotile N, Blasi F, Day H, Elliott J, Fuchs BC, Lanuti M, Caravan P. Optimization of a Collagen-Targeted PET Probe for Molecular Imaging of Pulmonary Fibrosis. J Nucl Med. 2017 Dec;58(12):1991-1996. doi: 10.2967/jnumed.117.193532. Epub 2017 Jun 13.

Montesi SB, Izquierdo-Garcia D, Desogere P, Abston E, Liang LL, Digumarthy S, Seethamraju R, Lanuti M, Caravan P, Catana C. Type I Collagen-targeted Positron Emission Tomography Imaging in Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis: First-in-Human Studies. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2019 Jul 15;200(2):258-261. doi: 10.1164/rccm.201903-0503LE. No abstract available.
